PROJECT TITLE:FY 2022 NATIONAL GEOLOGICAL & GEOPHYSICAL DATA PRESERVATION PROGRAM - FY 22 NGGDPPPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023DIGITAL SCANNING AND METADATA GENERATION OF 400 UNPUBLISHED GEOLOGICAL DATA FILES IN COLLECTION: THE MISSOURI GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (MGS) PROPOSES TO CREATE ARCHIVE QUALITY DIGITAL SCANS AND SAMPLE-LEVEL METADATA FOR 400 UNPUBLISHED GEOLOGICAL DATA FILES. THE FILES CONTAIN DIVERSE DATA THAT ARE UNAVAILABLE ELSEWHERE, ALONG WITH MAPS, GEOCHEMICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA, AND PHOTOGRAPHIC MATERIALS. SCAN FILES WILL BE REVIEWED FOR QUALITY AND COMPLETENESS; PAPER FILES WILL BE ARCHIVED IN THE MGS LIBRARY. THE SAMPLE-LEVEL METADATA GENERATED DURING THE PROJECT WILL BE POSTED ON THE MGS WEBPAGE IN THE MGS ONLINE BIBLIOGRAPHY AND SUBMITTED TO THE NATIONAL DIGITAL CATALOG (NDC); SCAN FILES WILL BE UPLOADED TO THE NDC. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS OF AND ACCESSIBILITY TO DATA THAT ARE USEFUL TO A WIDE RANGE OF GEOLOGIC AND PUBLIC ENTITIES, AND SAVE DATA DUPLICATION AND FIELD COSTS.PILOT PROJECT FOR CORE PHOTOGRAPHY: THE MISSOURI GEOLOGICAL SURVEY PROPOSES A PILOT PROJECT TO DEVELOP CORE PHOTOGRAPHY STANDARDS AND PROCEDURES, ARCHIVE PROTOCOLS, AND AN ARCGIS ONLINE APPLICATION, WITH THE GOAL OF A FUTURE CORE PHOTOGRAPHY PROJECT. ONLINE-ACCESSIBLE CORE PHOTOGRAPHS WILL ASSIST CUSTOMERS IN SELECTION OF CORES FOR STUDY, AND LIMIT PHYSICAL CORE HANDLING.CORE LOG DATABASE: THE MISSOURI GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (MGS) PROPOSES ENTRY OF 1,000 CORE LOGS INTO AN EXISTING CORE LOG DATABASE. THE LOGS CONTAIN DIVERSE DATA UNAVAILABLE ELSEWHERE THAT: ARE USEFUL TO A WIDE RANGE OF GEOLOGIC ENTITIES; SAVE DATA DUPLICATION AND FIELD COSTS; AND ARE ESSENTIAL FOR EVALUATION OF CRITICAL MINERAL POTENTIAL. CORE LOGS WILL BE PRIORITIZED BY PERMISSIVE GEOLOGY FOR CRITICAL MINERALS. SAMPLE-LEVEL METADATA, INCLUDING ALL CORE LOG TEXT AND GEOCHEMICAL DATA, WILL BE ENTERED INTO THE DATABASE, AND SUBMITTED TO THE NATIONAL DIGITAL CATALOG IN THE BOREHOLE TEMPLATE FORMAT. ORIGINAL LOGS WILL BE ARCHIVED IN A LIMITED-ACCESS AREA OF THE MGS LIBRARY. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS OF AND ACCESSIBILITY TO THE DATA. THE DATABASE FORMAT WILL MAXIMIZE SEARCH POTENTIAL AND PROVIDE GIS-COMPATIBLE DATA. THE PROJECT IS A CONTINUATION OF THE MGS 2019, 2020, AND 2021 NATIONAL GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA PRESERVATION PROGRAM CRITICAL MINERAL PRIORITY PROJECTS. THE DATA WILL ASSIST IN CRITICAL MINERAL EVALUATION AND DEVELOPMENT OF A SUBSURFACE THREE-DIMENSIONAL FRAMEWORK.

PROJECT TITLE:PRESERVATION OF GEOPHYSICAL WELL LOGS AND BOREHOLE VIDEO FOR BEDROCK WATER WELLS IN VERMONT: A HYDROGEOLOGIC RESOURCE FOR GROUNDWATER QUANTITY AND QUALITY PLANNINGPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023AWARD PURPOSE: BEDROCK WELLS DRILLED FOR DRINKING WATER PURPOSES ARE LIKE A 6" DIAMETER STRAW  THAT EXTENDS DEEP INTO A BEDROCK AQUIFER. USING MODERN GEOPHYSICAL LOGGING TOOLS, AN ENORMOUS  AMOUNT OF INFORMATION CAN BE LEARNED ABOUT THE WELL ITSELF AND THE "PLUMBING" OF THE  ENCOMPASSING BEDROCK AQUIFER, WHICH IS OF GREAT VALUE TO LOCAL, STATE, FEDERAL, AND PRIVATE SECTOR  SCIENTISTS FOR MAKING WATER QUANTITY AND QUALITY PLANNING DECISIONS. FROM 2012 - 2021, THE  VERMONT GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND AN ACADEMIC PARTNER AT THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT  PLATTSBURGH CONDUCTED GEOPHYSICAL LOGGING SURVEYS ON 48 BEDROCK WELLS IN VERMONT, AS PART OF  COLLABORATIVE HYDROGEOLOGY PROJECTS. EACH WELL WAS SURVEYED SEQUENTIALLY USING THE FOLLOWING  TOOLS:  1) GROUNDWATER TEMPERATURE  2) GROUNDWATER CONDUCTIVITY (SALINITY)  3) NATURAL RADIOACTIVITY (GAMMA)- HELPS DETERMINE THE ROCK TYPE.  4) WELL DIAMETER (CALIPER)- THE WELL IS WIDER WHERE BEDS AND CRACKS INTERSECT. 5) BOREHOLE IMAGER- CONSTRUCTS A 3-DIMENSIONAL WELL IMAGE USING RADAR WAVES.  6) HEAT PULSE FLOWMETER- TELLS WHAT DEPTH GROUNDWATER ENTERS THE WELL, WHETHER IT FLOWS  UP OR DOWN, AND AT WHAT VELOCITY.  7) BOREHOLE CAMERA- RECORDS A VIDEO OF THE INSIDE OF THE WELL.  THE GOAL OF THIS STUDY IS TO INTEGRATE THE GEOPHYSICAL WELL DATA FOR EACH OF THE 48 WELLS WITH A  GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS (GIS) WEB MAP ON THE VERMONT GEOLOGICAL SURVEY WEBSITE THAT  IS READILY AVAILABLE TO SCIENTISTS AND OTHER INTERESTED PARTIES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: A) DATA COLLATION- FOR EACH WELL, CREATE A COMPUTER INFORMATION (METADATA) FILE PROVIDING LOGGING DATE, LOCATION INFORMATION, AND WELL DRILLER REPORT INFORMATION. CONVERT  BOREHOLE CAMERA VIDEO INTO A COMMON VIDEO FORMAT. B) PRODUCTION OF WELL LOG GRAPHICS- CONSTRUCT A GIS BASE MAP THAT SHOWS THE LOCATIONS  OF ALL WELLS LOGGED IN THE CONTEXT OF MAJOR GEOGRAPHIC AND GEOLOGIC FEATURES. USING THE  COLLATED DATA FILES FROM PROCEDURE A, PRODUCE A HIGH-QUALITY GRAPHICS FILE FOR EACH WELL.  C) PUT MATERIALS ONLINE INTEGRATE GRAPHICS FILES FOR ALL 48 WELLS AND GIS BASE MAP FROM  PROCEDURE B TO MAKE AN INTERACTIVE WEB MAP. UPLOAD TO THE VERMONT GEOLOGICAL SURVEY  WEBSITE. VIDEO DATA WILL BE AVAILABLE VIA FILE TRANSFER PROTOCOL (FTP) SERVICES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: AN UPDATEABLE AND INTERACTIVE WEB MAP DATA REPOSITORY  THAT IS READILY AVAILABLE TO THE BENEFICIARIES BELOW TO INFORM GROUNDWATER QUANTITY AND QUALITY  PLANNING DECISIONS.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: LOCAL, STATE, FEDERAL, AND PRIVATE SECTOR SCIENTISTS AND INTERESTED PARTIES.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: DR. EDWIN ROMANOWICZ, WHO WAS AN INTEGRAL PART OF THE ENTIRE GEOPHYSICAL LOGGING PROJECT FROM 2012-2021, WAS INCLUDED IN THE PROPOSAL AS A SUBRECIPIENT.

PROJECT TITLE:RESCUING DAMAGED CORE, CONVERTING 6 PREVIOUSLY PUBLISHED MAPS TO LEVEL 3 GEMS, AND COMPILING CRITICAL MINERAL BOREHOLE DATA FOR EARTH MRIPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: TRANSFERRING 9800 FEET OF ROCK CORE FROM 980 CARDBOARD BOXES DAMAGED DURING A 2021 SPRING FLOODING EVENT TO WATERPROOF PLASTIC CORRUGATED BOXES WITH COVERS, CONVERTING SIX PREVIOUSLY PUBLISHED GEOLOGIC MAPS IN THE MIDDLE TENNESSEE MINERAL DISTRICT TO NEW DIGITAL STANDARDS, UPDATING REGISTRY OF SCIENTIFIC COLLECTIONS COLLECTION-LEVEL METADATA RECORDS FROM 16 COLLECTIONS TO THE NEW METADATA CONVENTION, AND COMPILING BOREHOLE DATA FOR 400 MINERAL TEST HOLES IN THE MIDDLE TENNESSEE MINERAL DISTRICT.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: FOR PRIORITY 1 - PRESERVE GEOSCIENCE DATA AND MATERIALS - OBJECTIVE 1: REPLACING DAMAGED CORE BOXES IN THE TENNESSEE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY ROCK CORE COLLECTION, SURVEY STAFF WILL COMPLETE THE TRANSFER OF 9800 FEET OF ROCK CORE FROM DAMAGED CARDBOARD BOXES TO NEW WATERPROOF PLASTIC CORRUGATED BOXES, PRESERVING SUBSURFACE DATA AND SAMPLE RESOURCES PRIMARILY FROM EXPLORATION ACTIVITIES IN THE MIDDLE TENNESSEE MINERAL DISTRICT BASIN BRINE PATH MINERAL SYSTEM, PART OF AN EARTH MAPPING RESOURCES INITIATIVE THAT WILL ULTIMATELY SUPPORT THE U.S. GEOFRAMEWORK INITIATIVE, THE GOAL OF WHICH IS TO PRODUCE A SEAMLESS GEOLOGIC MAP OF THE UNITED STATES BY 2030. FOR OBJECTIVE 2: CONVERTING SIX PUBLISHED 7.5-MINUTE QUADRANGLE GEOLOGIC MAPS TO LEVEL 3 UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY GEOLOGIC MAP SCHEMA FORMAT, SURVEY STAFF WILL COMPLETE THE CONVERSION OF THE BELLWOOD, CARTHAGE, DIXON, DODSON BRANCH, GAINESBORO, AND GRANVILLE GEOLOGIC MAPS THAT ARE ADJACENT TO EACH OTHER AND PROVIDE AN EAST-WEST TRANSECT ACROSS AN EARTH MAPPING RESOURCES INITIATIVE MULTI-STATE FOCUS AREA CALLED THE SOUTH-CENTRAL KENTUCKY - NORTH CENTRAL TENNESSEE MINERAL DISTRICT THAT HOSTS MISSISSIPPI VALLEY TYPE DEPOSITS CONTAINING SPHALERITE, GERMANIUM, GALLIUM, AND COBALT. FOR OBJECTIVE 3: ADDITIONAL FUNDING REQUEST TO UPDATE THE REGISTRY OF SCIENTIFIC COLLECTIONS, SURVEY STAFF WILL UPDATE COLLECTION-LEVEL METADATA RECORDS FROM 16 COLLECTIONS TO THE NEW METADATA CONVENTION TO IMPROVE DISCOVERABILITY AND ACCESS TO THE COLLECTIONS. FOR PRIORITY 2 - IDENTIFYING CRITICAL MINERAL RESOURCES, SURVEY STAFF WILL COMPILE BOREHOLE DATA FOR APPROXIMATELY 400 MINERAL TEST HOLES IN THE MIDDLE TENNESSEE MINERAL DISTRICT THAT HOSTS PHASE 3 AND PHASE 4 CRITICAL MINERALS BARITE, FLUORSPAR, GALLIUM, GERMANIUM, AND ZINC USING THE PRESCRIBED BOREHOLE METADATA TEMPLATE AND UPLOADING IT TO THE REGISTRY OF SCIENTIFIC COLLECTIONS SO SOCIETY WILL ULTIMATELY BENEFIT BY HAVING THE MEANS TO DIGITALLY SEARCH FOR AND REVIEW THE INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THEM SINCE THE MINERAL TEST HOLE INFORMATION CURRENTLY ONLY EXISTS AS PAPER FILES.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: CITIZENS OF TENNESSEE, AS WELL AS THOSE OF THE UNITED STATES, WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PRESERVATION OF UNIQUE GEOLOGIC DATA OF SIGNIFICANT VALUE THAT HAS THE POTENTIAL TO CONTRIBUTE TO NATION-WIDE SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC PRIORITIES. SINCE 1831 THE TENNESSEE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY HAS BEEN COLLECTING DATA REGARDING TENNESSEE'S MINERAL RESOURCES. ALTHOUGH MUCH OF THIS INFORMATION HAS BEEN COMPILED AND MADE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH PUBLISHED REPORTS, A SIGNIFICANT AMOUNT EXISTS ONLY IN THE FORM OF PAPER DOCUMENTS STORED IN FILE AND MAP CABINETS IN AGENCY OFFICES AND WAREHOUSES ACROSS THE STATE WHERE UP UNTIL RECENTLY THEY HAVE NOT BEEN CATALOGED AND THEIR EXISTENCE AND WHEREABOUTS MADE KNOWN TO THE PUBLIC, RESEARCHERS, AND INDUSTRY THROUGH A PUBLIC-FACING INTERFACE SUCH AS THE REGISTRY OF SCIENTIFIC COLLECTIONS.

PROJECT TITLE:FY22 NGGDPP PROPOSAL FROM MINNESOTA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (MGS) PRIORITIES INCLUDE SUBSURFACERESOURCES AND CRITICAL MINERALS.PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2022DESCRIPTION OF PURPOSE: THE ACTIVITY PROPOSED BY UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA, MINNESOTA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, FOR COMPLETION IN 2022/2023, WITH SUPPORT FROM THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, NATIONAL GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA PRESERVATION PROGRAM, IS MEANT TO BE AN ANNUAL INCREMENT OF EFFORT FIRST AUTHORIZED BY THE ENERGY POLICY ACT OF 2005, THAT IS MEANT TO ENSURE THE PRESERVATION AND AVAILABILITY OF PUBLIC GEOSCIENCE OBSERVATIONS SUCH AS GEOLOGISTS' DESCRIPTIONS, MEASUREMENTS SUCH AS GEOPHYSICAL AND GEOCHEMICAL DETERMINATIONS, AND SPECIMENS SUCH AS SEDIMENTS AND ROCKS, THAT ARE NEEDED BY SOCIETY TO ENSURE OPTIMAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, HAZARDS RESILIENCE, AND TO SUPPORT RESEARCH ON OUR PLANET AND ITS LIFE.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE WORK PROPOSED FOR THIS COMING YEAR ADDRESSES ADMINISTRATION PRIORITIES REGARDING THE ECONOMY, AND PROGRAM PRIORITIES REGARDING SUBSURFACE RESOURCES AND CRITICAL MINERALS. THE WORK WILL BE CARRIED OUT BY MINNESOTA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA, IN COOPERATION WITH THE NATURAL RESOURCES RESEARCH INSTITUTE OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA DULUTH, AND THE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES. THE WORK INCLUDES PRESERVATION OF FIELD DATA, DEVELOPMENT OF A GEOPHYSICAL DATABASE, THE THIRD PHASE OF WORK ON DRILL CUTTINGS, THE PLANNED SECOND PHASE OF INVENTORY, ENHANCEMENT, AND MAJOR FACILITY EXPENDITURES AT THE DRILL CORE LIBRARY, AS WELL AS ATTENDANCE BY TWO STAFF AT A DATA PRESERVATION WORKSHOP. ALSO, WE PROPOSE TO UPDATE MAPS OF MINERAL DEPOSITS AND DISTRICTS, GEOLOGICAL MAPPING DATABASES NEEDED FOR ASSESSMENT OF MINERAL POTENTIAL, BOREHOLE DATA, AND INFORMATION STRATEGY DEVELOPMENT, AS WELL AS PREPARATION FOR AND ATTENDANCE AT A CRITICAL MINERALS WORKSHOP.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE DELIVERABLES WILL BE PRESERVED FIELD DATA, A NEW GEOPHYSICAL DATABASE, ENHANCED DRILL CUTTINGS COLLECTIONS, AN ENHANCED DRILL CORE LIBRARY, PARTICIPATION IN A NATIONAL DATA PRESERVATION WORKSHOP, UPDATED COMPILATION OF MINERAL DEPOSITS AND DISTRICTS, MAPPING TO SUPPORT USGS MINERALS-RELATED PLANNING, A COMPILATION AND DOCUMENTATION OF DRILLHOLE DATA, PARTICIPATION IN A NATIONAL CRITICAL MINERALS WORKSHOP AND RELATED ACTIVITY, AND FOLLOW-UP TO STRATEGIC PLANNING. THE OUTCOMES WILL BE BETTER PUBLIC INFORMATION AND PLANNING FOR GEOSCIENCE OBSERVATIONS, MEASUREMENTS, AND COLLECTIONS NEEDED BY THE PEOPLE OF MINNESOTA TO SUPPORT RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, HAZARDS RESILIENCE, AND RESEARCH.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE PEOPLE OF MINNESOTA.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THE NATURAL RESOURCES RESEARCH INSTITUTE OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA DULUTH WILL FOCUS ON ROLES IN MAPPING TO SUPPORT MINERALS-RELATED PLANNING, PARTICIPATION IN A NATIONAL CRITICAL MINERALS WORKSHOP AND RELATED ACTIVITY, AND FOLLOW-UP TO STRATEGIC PLANNING. THE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL FOCUS ON ROLES IN ENHANCEMENT OF THE DRILL CORE LIBRARY, PARTICIPATION IN A NATIONAL DATA PRESERVATION WORKSHOP, UPDATED COMPILATION OF MINERAL DEPOSITS AND DISTRICTS, COMPILATION AND DOCUMENTATION OF DRILLHOLE DATA, PARTICIPATION IN A NATIONAL CRITICAL MINERALS WORKSHOP AND RELATED ACTIVITY, AND FOLLOW-UP TO STRATEGIC PLANNING.

PROJECT TITLE: DATA PRESERVATION WORKSHOP AND CRITICAL MINERALS BOREHOLE INITIATIVE AND LONG-RANGE PLANPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023THIS PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF COMPILING HISTORIC BOREHOLE DATA ON PEYTON CREEK AND HICKORY VALLEY PHOSPHATE DEPOSITS AND THE BATESVILLE MANGANESE DISTRICT. DATA AND DESCRIPTIONS OF 23 HOLES IN PEYTON CREEK, 17 HOLES IN HICKORY VALLEY, 30 HOLES IN THE BATESVILLE DISTRICT, AND 75 PHOSPHATE AND MANGANESE PROSPECTS IN INDEPENDENCE COUNTY ARE AVAILABLE TO ADD TO THE TEMPLATE. THESE PHOSPHATE AND MANGANESE DEPOSITS WILL BE THE GOAL FOR THIS YEAR'S PROJECT WITH PLANS FOR SIMILAR ADDITION OF DATA FROM OTHER CRITICAL MINERAL DEPOSITS SUCH AS LEAD AND ZINC AND OVER 3,300 BAUXITE WELL LOGS.THE BOREHOLE DATA WILL SUPPLEMENT GEOLOGIC MAPPING RECENTLY COMPLETED IN THE BATESVILLE MANGANESE DISTRICT. FUTURE PLANS FOR INCLUSION OF CORE DATA RELATED TO LEAD AND ZINC WILL COMPLEMENT PROPOSED MAPPING IN THE NORTHEAST ARKANSAS LEAD AND ZINC DISTRICT.THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO INVOLVE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A LONG-RANGE PRESERVATION PLAN FOR CRITICAL MINERAL INFORMATION. THIS PLAN WILL INCLUDE COMPILATION OF ALL KNOWN BORINGS IN THE STATE PERTINENT TO CRITICAL MINERALS, EVALUATION OF THE CURRENTLY AVAILABLE DATA FOR THESE BOREHOLES, AND DEVELOPMENT OF A TIMELINE FOR COMPLETING THE INPUT OF THIS DATA. AN ADDITIONAL PART OF THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION PLAN IS TO RE-BOX, PHOTOGRAPH, AND DESCRIBE A PORTION OF THESE SAMPLES. MANY OF THE BOXES THAT THESE CORE AND CUTTINGS ARE STORED IN HAVE DETERIORATED OVER TIME. THIS WILL BEGIN THE PROCESS OF TRANSFERRING THESE SAMPLES INTO MORE DURABLE CONTAINERS AS WELL AS TAKING THE OPPORTUNITY TO PHOTOGRAPH AND DESCRIBE THE SAMPLES FOR THE PURPOSE OF MAKING THIS DATA AVAILABLE ON OUR WEBSITE. INFORMATION GLEANED FROM THIS PROCESS WILL BE USED TO CREATE A TIMELINE FOR THE FULL PRESERVATION AND DESCRIPTION OF OUR CRITICAL MINERAL BORINGS.THE END GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PRESERVE CRITICAL MINERAL DATA AND SAMPLES THAT ARE IN DANGER OF BEING LOST WHILE MAKING THEM MORE AVAILABLE TO INTERESTED PARTIES. THIS DATA IS OF INTEREST TO FEDERAL AND STATE GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES RESPONSIBLE FOR RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND DECREASING RELIANCE ON FOREIGN SOURCES, PRIVATE INDUSTRY SEEKING TO DEVELOP AND EXTRACT THESE RESOURCES, AND ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS WILL ALSO BENEFIT FROM THIS DATA.

PROJECT TITLE:ALASKA GMC DATABASE UPGRADE, HYPERSPECTRAL SCANNER, AND CORE RESCUEPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, DIVISION OF GEOLOGICAL & GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS (DGGS) IS STATUTORILY MANDATED TO COLLECT, ARCHIVE, MANAGE, AND DISSEMINATE GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA ON THE SUBSURFACE ENERGY RESOURCES, MINERAL RESOURCES, AND GEOLOGIC HAZARDS OF THE STATE. ALASKA IS A SUCCESSFUL GLOBAL COMPETITOR FOR INVESTMENT DOLLARS MARKED FOR OIL & GAS AND MINERAL RESOURCES; THE STATE COMPARES PARTICULARLY FAVORABLY TO OTHER MINING JURISDICTIONS AROUND THE WORLD-ALASKA RANKED 5TH FOR MINERAL POTENTIAL AND 5TH FOR OVERALL INVESTMENT ATTRACTIVENESS OUT OF 77 GLOBAL MINING JURISDICTIONS ACCORDING TO THE FRASER INSTITUTE'S ANNUAL SURVEY OF MINING COMPANIES IN 2020. ALASKA'S RESOURCES COLLECTIVELY REPRESENT A SIGNIFICANT PROPORTION OF UNITED STATES' DOMESTIC GOLD, SILVER, COPPER, AND BASE-METAL RESOURCES AND INDICATE THAT THERE ARE STILL EXTREMELY LARGE MINERAL DEPOSITS TO BE DISCOVERED AND DEVELOPED IN THE STATE. SIGNIFICANT RESOURCES OF CRITICAL MINERALS IN DEPOSITS AND PRESENT AS BY-PRODUCTS IN MANY PRECIOUS- AND BASE-METAL DEPOSITS PROMISE FUTURE DOMESTIC RESOURCES NEEDED FOR TWENTY-FIRST-CENTURY TECHNOLOGIES. EVEN WITH ALASKA'S LARGE, RECOGNIZED MINERAL ENDOWMENT AND OIL AND GAS RESOURCES, THE STATE MUST DEVELOP STRATEGIES SUCH AS GEOLOGIC DATA AND SAMPLE REPOSITORIES AND ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY SERVICES TO ATTRACT COMPANIES TO THE STATE. ROBUST DATA AND SERVICES ALSO PROVIDE A FOUNDATION FOR RESEARCHERS, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, AND THE PUBLIC TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS ABOUT NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND POTENTIAL DEVELOPMENT.THE NATIONAL GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA PRESERVATION PROGRAM (NGGDPP), FOR USGS 2022 PROGRAM ANNOUNCEMENT G22AS00033, AWARDED DGGS FUNDING FOR TWO PROGRAM OBJECTIVES. THE FIRST OBJECTIVE INCLUDES TWO SIGNIFICANT UPGRADES TO THE GEOLOGIC MATERIALS CENTER (GMC), ALASKA'S PREMIER GEOSCIENCE MATERIALS AND DATA REPOSITORY. A HYPERSPECTRAL SCANNER WILL BE PURCHASED THAT IMAGES AND COLLECTS HIGH-RESOLUTION PHOTOGRAPHY OF CORES AND SAMPLES STORED AT THE REPOSITORY. MODERN SOPHISTICATED ANALYSIS OF ARCHIVED SAMPLES SUCH AS HYPERSPECTRAL IMAGING IS WIDELY RECOGNIZED AS A COST-EFFECTIVE ALTERNATIVE TO THE TREMENDOUS EXPENSE OF CORE DRILLING AND SAMPLING IN OFTEN REMOTE AREAS OF ALASKA. FUNDING IS ALSO PROVIDED FOR BUILDING OUT ELECTRICAL AND DATA WIRING NECESSARY FOR INSTALLATION OF THE SCANNER AND DATABASE UPGRADES TO COLLECT, DELIVER, AND ARCHIVE VERY LARGE DATA FILES. THE ABILITY TO ASSOCIATE UNDERUTILIZED LEGACY IMAGES AND NEW DATA FILES GENERATED BY SCANNING TECHNIQUES WITH INVENTORY RECORDS AND SERVE THE DATA OUT TO THE PUBLIC WILL DRAMATICALLY INCREASE THE GMC DATABASE'S COMPATIBILITY WITH FAIR DATA MANAGEMENT PRINCIPLES (FINDABLE, ACCESSIBLE, INTEROPERABLE AND REUSABLE), THEREBY INCREASING THE UTILITY AND VALUE OF THE GMC'S HOLDINGS IN RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT. AS PROOF OF CONCEPT, DGGS ANTICIPATES 1,500 LEGACY PHOTO AND IMAGE RECORDS PLUS METADATA FOR SEVERAL TEST HYPERSPECTRAL SCANS WILL BE DELIVERED TO THE NATIONAL DIGITAL CATALOG. DELIVERABLES WILL ALSO INCLUDE APPLICATION SUPPORT AND DATABASE DOCUMENTATION: SOURCE CODE, SCHEMA, AND DATABASE STRUCTURE.THE NGGDPP WILL ALSO PROVIDE FUNDING TO DGGS TO RESCUE AND ACCESSION 1,000 CORE BOXES REMAINING FROM THE UNION BAY AND DUKE ISLAND PGE-CU-NI-CR DEPOSITS. DGGS WILL PROCURE NEW CORE BOXES FOR THE REMAINING 1,000 BOXES OF CORE, REBOX THE COLLECTION AS NEEDED, HARVEST METADATA FROM THE BOXES AND DOCUMENTS, ACCESSION THE COLLECTION, AND PROVIDE METADATA RECORDS TO THE NATIONAL DIGITAL CATALOG. IN TOTAL, THE PROJECT IMPLEMENTS DGGS' PLAN TO DEVELOP HIGH-VALUE DATA PRODUCTS FROM THE HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS OF SAMPLES STORED AT THE GMC, A NEED CLEARLY IDENTIFIED BY STAKEHOLDERS IN ALASKA'S RESOURCE COMMUNITY.

PROJECT TITLE:DATA PRESERVATION OF OKLAHOMA GEOLOGICAL RESOURCESPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 6/1/2022 THROUGH 5/31/2023AWARD DESCRIPTIONTHE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO SUPPORT THE EFFORT TO DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE DATABASE OF PRESERVED GEOSCIENCE DATA AVAILABLE THROUGH THE OGS ONLINE WEB APPLICATION BY GENERATING SCANNED DIGITAL CONTENT AND INVENTORY RECORDS OF COLLECTIONS HOUSED AT THE OGS-OPIC FACILITY THAT HAVE NOT YET BEEN INVENTORIED OR PRESERVED DIGITALLY.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMEDTHE WORK THAT WILL BE EXECUTED THROUGH THIS PROJECT WILL CONCOMITANTLY SATISFY THE NGGDPP FY 2022 PRIORITY 1 OBJECTIVE TO INVENTORY, PRESERVE, ARCHIVE, AND/OR MODERNIZE GEOLOGIC, GEOPHYSICAL, AND ENGINEERING DATA, MAPS, NOTEBOOKS, PUBLICATIONS, WELL LOGS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND SAMPLES BY ACCOMPLISHING THE FOLLOWING GOALS:(1) CONVERSION OF PAPER RECORDS AND/OR ANALOG DATA TO DIGITAL FORMATS FOR PRESERVATION.(2) CREATION OF METADATA OF GEOSCIENCE DATA AT THE INDIVIDUAL SAMPLE LEVEL.(3) ARCHIVING OF GEOSCIENCE MATERIALS.(4) IMPLEMENTING QUALITY CONTROL OF PROJECT DATA AND EXISTING MASTER WELL RECORDS DATABASE FOR PUBLIC CONSUMPTION.DELIVERABLESSCANNED RASTER IMAGES OF 10,000 WELL LOGS AND 2,000 CORE PHOTOS, AND ASSOCIATED METADATA, WILL BE UPLOADED TO THE NATIONAL DIGITAL ARCHIVE AS WELL AS THE OGS ONLINE WELL VIEWER APPLICATION.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES THE PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL FACILITATE THE DISSEMINATION OF GEOSCIENCE INFORMATION TO INDUSTRY PARTICIPANTS, THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY, AND CITIZENS, TO PROMOTE THE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT OF STATE RESOURCES THROUGH BEST PRACTICES AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP.

PROJECT TITLE:PRIORITY 1: BUTTE STOPE BOOKS & PRIORITY 2: PRESERVING MONTANA'S CRITICAL MINERAL RESOURCE DATAPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023THE MONTANA BUREAU OF MINES AND GEOLOGY WILL USE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) NATIONAL  GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA PRESERVATION PROGRAM FUNDING IN FISCAL YEAR 2022 -2023 TO  PERFORM THREE PROJECT ACTIVITIES:  1. COMPLETE AN INVENTORY, DIGITIZE, AND CREATE METADATA FOR 1:1500-SCALE MAPS CONTAINED IN STOPE  BOOKS FOR UNDERGROUND MINES IN THE SUMMIT VALLEY (BUTTE) MONTANA MINING DISTRICT. IN 2019 WE  USED FUNDING TO SUPPORT SCANNING OF 50 STOPE BOOKS THAT WERE IN DANGER OF LOSS. OUR CURRENT  PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL PRESERVE DATA FOR AN ADDITIONAL 153 STOPE BOOKS THAT ARE CURRENTLY OWNED  BY THE BUTTE -SILVER BOW COUNTY ARCHIVES. WE WILL ENABLE FULL PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE DIGITAL DATA  INCLUDING THROUGH THE MONTANA BUREAU OF MINES AND GEOLOGY WEBSITE. 2. BUILD A ROCK SPECIMEN STORAGE FACILITY ON THE MONTANA TECH CAMPUS IN BUTTE, MONTANA. OUR  OFFICE HAS ENGAGED IN PLANNING, DESIGN, AND CONSTRUCTION COST ESTIMATES FOR THIS SPECIMEN STORAGE  FACILITY FOR THE PAST 18 MONTHS. THE BUILDING WILL INCLUDE ABOUT 2,000 SQFT OF SPECIMEN STORAGE  AND 1400 SQFT OF LAB/PREP AND AUXILIARY STORAGE. THE DESIGN FOR THIS FACILITY WAS LARGELY BASED ON  THAT OF OUR ANACONDA RESEARCH COLLECTION BUILDING. THE DESIGN EMPHASIZES FLEXIILITY TO  ACCOMMODATE WORK SPACE FOR SAMPLE PREPARATION, DATA ENTRY, AND ARCHIVAL STORAGE FOR OUR  GROWING SPECIMEN COLLECTION.  3. CONTINUE OUR EFFORTS TO SERVE HIGH-QUALITY CRITICAL COMMODITY DATA THROUGH THE MONTANA  BUREAU OF MINES AND GEOLOGY WEBSITE. MONTANA, THE "TREASURE STATE", IS AN IMPORTANT REGION OF  THE U.S. FOR CRITICAL MINERAL RESOURCES BECAUSE OF ITS MINING HISTORY AND A DIVERSE ARRAY OF  OVERLAPPING MINERAL SYSTEMS AND DEPOSITS. WE WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME STAFF GEOLOGIST TO FOCUS DATA  COMPILATION ON REGIONS OF THE STATE WITH CURRENT MINING, PAST PRODUCTION AND HIGH POTENTIAL FOR  CRITICAL COMMODITY RESOURCES. THIS PROJECT WILL MAKE SIGNIFICANT HEADWAY TOWARDS OUR VISION OF  DELIVERING HIGH-QUALITY CRITICAL COMMODITY DATA, IN DIGITAL (MAP AND WEB-BASED DATA SERVICE)  FORMATS TO THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY AND TO THE PUBLIC.

PROJECT TITLE:CONSERVATION AND CURATION OF THE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY OF ALABAMA FOSSIL COLLECTIONSPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023WITH FUNDING THROUGH THE USGS NATIONAL GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA PRESERVATION PROGRAM, FOR FISCAL YEAR 2022, THE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY OF ALABAMA (GSA) WILL CONSERVE 1,600 FOSSIL SPECIMENS THAT ARE CURRENTLY STORED IN SUBSTANDARD CONDITIONS. THE SPECIMENS WILL BE IMPROVED BY PRINTING NEW ARCHIVAL-GRADE LABELS TO REPLACE ILLEGIBLE AND DETERIORATING HAND-WRITTEN LABELS FROM THE LATE 19TH AND EARLY 20TH CENTURIES, INSTALLING ARCHIVAL FOAM PADDING IN THE SPECIMEN TRAYS TO LESSEN DAMAGING SHOCK FROM TRAY AND CABINET MOVEMENTS, AND WRITING CATALOG NUMBERS ON THE FOSSILS TO IMPROVE COLLECTIONS ORGANIZATION. THESE 1,600 SPECIMENS WILL ALSO BE PHOTOGRAPHED IN A LOSSLESS DIGITAL FORMAT TO PROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH AN INTERNET-ACCESSIBLE VISUAL RECORD OF EACH OF THESE CATALOG ENTRIES. UPDATED METADATA FOR THE ENTIRE FOSSIL COLLECTION AS WELL AS INTERNET ADDRESSES OF THE SPECIMEN PHOTOS WILL BE UPLOADED IN A MICROSOFT EXCEL FILE TO THE SCIENCEBASE.GOV WEBSITE USING THE UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) TEMPLATE. THE METADATA AND IMAGES WILL ALSO BE PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE ON THE GSA WEBSITE. A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE USGS THAT WILL DOCUMENT AND SUMMARIZE THE RESULTS OF THE PROJECT. THE BENEFICIARIES OF THE IMPROVED GSA PALEONTOLOGY COLLECTIONS INCLUDE COMMERCIAL AND ACADEMIC GEOSCIENTISTS WHO USE THE INFORMATION FOR GEOLOGIC MAPPING AND STRATIGRAPHIC PURPOSES INCLUDING ENERGY PRODUCTION, INVESTIGATING GROUNDWATER RESOURCES, RESEARCH INTO PAST CLIMATE CHANGE AND HOW IT COMPARES TO CURRENT CLIMATE CHANGE, AND OTHER PALEOENVIRONMENTAL STUDIES. NUMEROUS COLLEGE STUDENTS HAVE UTILIZED THE GSA COLLECTIONS IN RECENT YEARS FOR THEIR GRADUATE RESEARCH PROJECTS ON A VARIETY OF TOPICS. ENERGY COMPANIES MAY ALSO INCORPORATE THIS FOSSIL INFORMATION INTO THE PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES SECTION OF THEIR REQUIRED ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENTS WHEN CONSTRUCTING OR MOVING PIPELINES. FINALLY, THE GENERAL PUBLIC MAY ACCESS THIS INFORMATION IN ORDER TO PURSUE THEIR PERSONAL RECREATIONAL PALEONTOLOGICAL INTERESTS.

PROJECT TITLE:UTAH GEOLOGICAL SURVEY FY2022 GEOLOGIC DATA PRESERVATION PROJECTPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023AS PART OF THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) FY2022 NATIONAL GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA PRESERVATION PROGRAM (NGGDPP) FUNDING, THE UTAH GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (UGS) PLANS TO DIGITIZE GEOTECHNICAL EXPLORATION DATA FOR A 3D GEOLOGIC SUBSURFACE DATABASE; TO SCAN AND CREATE METADATA FOR GEOLOGIC DOCUMENTS, MAPS, AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHY, AND OTHER DATA; RESCUE AT-RISK ROCK CORE; PHOTOGRAPH ROCK CORE; IMPROVE THE PHYSICAL INFRASTRUCTURE SUPPORTING OUR COLLECTIONS; ATTEND THE 2022 DATA RESCUE AND PRESERVATION WORKSHOP; CREATE A GIS PRODUCT FOR THE JARVIS PEAK QUADRANGLE; DIGITIZE AND ARCHIVE HISTORICAL MINERAL DOCUMENT FILES; COMPILE LITHIUM AND COBALT MINERAL GEOCHEMICAL DATA; COMPILE INTRUSIVE GEOLOGIC UNIT DATA; UPDATE THE MINERAL RESOURCES OF UTAH WEB MAP; AND ATTEND THE 2022 EARTH MAPPING RESOURCES INITIATIVE (EARTH MRI) CRITICAL MINERAL WORKSHOP.THIS PROJECT IS ANTICIPATED TO CREATE ADDITIONAL DATA FOR INCLUSION IN THE UTAH 3D SUBSURFACE DATABASE, THE UGS GEODATA ARCHIVE, THE UTAH AERIAL IMAGERY DATABASE, THE UTAH GEOLOGIC MAP PORTAL, AND THE UTAH CORE RESEARCH CENTER CORE INVENTORY. A GEMS COMPLIANT DIGITAL GEOLOGIC MAP OF THE JARVIS PEAK QUADRANGLE WILL BE PRODUCED. A REPORT DETAILING THE UGS CRITICAL MINERALS DATA PRESERVATION PLAN WILL BE PRODUCED.THE UGS PROVIDES TIMELY, OBJECTIVE SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION ABOUT UTAH'S GEOLOGIC ENVIRONMENT, RESOURCES, AND HAZARDS TO ALL UTAHNS TO IMPROVE THEIR LIVES THROUGH INFORMED DECISION MAKING. THE UGS IS THE ONLY PUBLIC ORGANIZATION IN UTAH THAT ACTIVELY COLLECTS AND MANAGES VARIOUS GEOLOGIC INFORMATION RESOURCES OF UTAH, IS CHARGED IN STATE CODE (SECTION 79-3-202, HTTP://LE.UTAH.GOV/XCODE/TITLE79/CHAPTER3 /79-3.HTML) WITH ARCHIVING GEOLOGIC DATA, AND IS THE ONLY UTAH ORGANIZATION TO PROVIDE GEOLOGIC MAPS AND DATA, GEOLOGIC-HAZARD REPORTS/DATA, AND SIGNIFICANT, STATEWIDE COVERAGE OF HISTORICAL AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHY ONLINE. THE UGS ALSO MANAGES THE UCRC, THE REGION'S ONLY PUBLICLY AVAILABLE AND MOST COMPLETE COLLECTION OF GEOLOGIC CORE AND CUTTINGS FROM UTAH. PRESERVING AND ENABLING EASY ACCESS TO THESE MATERIALS IS CRITICAL TO THE LONG-TERM SURVIVAL OF IMPORTANT GEOLOGIC DATA, ENABLING AND IMPROVING NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP, LOWERING DEVELOPMENT AND INFRASTRUCTURE COSTS, PROTECTING THE PUBLIC FROM GEOLOGIC HAZARDS, AND FULFILLING OUR STATUTORY MISSION. IT IS CRITICAL THAT THIS DATA BE CATALOGED AND PRESERVED FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE USE, AS DEMANDS FOR NATURAL RESOURCES, DEVELOPMENT IN GEOLOGICALLY HAZARDOUS AREAS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES INCREASE. INDUSTRY, CONSULTANTS, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES (FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL), ACADEMIA, EDUCATORS, STUDENTS, AND THE PUBLIC CURRENTLY USE COLLECTIONS AND DATA HELD BY THE UGS IN A VARIETY OF PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS. THIS PROJECT WILL ENABLE THE UGS TO CATALOG AND DIGITALLY CONVERT A PORTION OF OUR UNIQUE HOLDINGS FOR EASIER ACCESS BY USERS, AS WELL AS PRESERVING THEM LONG-TERM FOR THE FUTURE.

PROJECT TITLE:WASHINGTON DATA PRESERVATION 2022, PRIORITY 1 AND PRIORITY 2PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023SUMMARY FOR PRIORITY 1THE OBJECTIVE OF PRIORITY 1 IS TO DIGITIZE BOREHOLE RECORDS COLLECTED BY THE WASHINGTON GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (WGS) AND MAKE THEM AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC. THESE RECORDS HAVE BEEN COLLECTED BY THE SURVEY FROM MUNICIPAL GOVERNMENTS AS PART OF THE BUILDING PERMITTING AND CONSTRUCTION PROCESS. MAKING THESE REPORTS AVAILABLE DIGITALLY, ALONG WITH QUERYABLE ATTRIBUTES, ALLOWS ENGINEERS, GEOLOGISTS, PLANNERS, AND OTHERS TO SAVE TIME AND MONEY ON PROJECTS BY BETTER UNDERSTANDING SUBSURFACE CONDITIONS. THE DIGITIZATION PROCESS INVOLVES GEOREFERENCING PREVIOUSLY SCANNED PROJECT MAPS TO OBTAIN ACCURATE BOREHOLE LOCATIONS IN GIS, ATTRIBUTING TABULAR DATA, SUCH AS GEOLOGIC CONDITIONS RECORDED IN THE BOREHOLE LOG, THEN APPENDING THE PRODUCED RECORDS TO OUR STATEWIDE SUBSURFACE DATABASE AND ADDING METADATA RECORDS FOR EACH ON THE NATIONAL DATA CATALOG. THIS DATASET IS ONE OF THE MOST POPULAR AT THE SURVEY, RECEIVING ON AVERAGE A THOUSAND UNIQUE VISITS PER MONTH ON OUR WEBSITE.SUMMARY FOR PRIORITY 2THE OBJECTIVE OF PRIORITY 2 IS TO CONTINUE SUPPORTING THE EARTH MRI OBJECTIVES BY IDENTIFYING AREAS THAT HAVE THE POTENTIAL FOR HOSTING CRITICAL MINERALS. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE DIGITIZING MAPS OF HISTORIC MINING DISTRICTS, AND MODERNIZING AN ANTIQUATED DATASET FOR INACTIVE AND ABANDONED MINE LANDS (IAML). COMBINATION OF BOTH PREVIOUS ITEMS WITH OTHER STATE HELD MINERAL-RELATED DATASETS WILL BE THE FOUNDATION FOR A NEW DATABASE THAT SERVES TO BRING ALL MINERALS DATA TOGETHER ENHANCING THE ABILITY OF FUTURE RESEARCHERS TO EXPLORE AND UNDERSTAND WASHINGTON STATE'S MINERALS DATA. THE MINING DISTRICT DATASET AND IAML WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE USGS THROUGH THE NDC AND PROVIDED TO THE USMIN PROGRAM FOR CONSIDERATION OF INCLUSION IN THEIR DATABASE. THE MINERAL AND MINE OCCURRENCE DATASET WAS PROCESSED IN AN EARLIER NGGDPP GRANT (GS19AS00009) FOR MINERAL TARGETS IDENTIFIED IN PHASE II AND ANTICIPATED FOR PHASES III AND IV. THIS DATASET WILL BE SIMILARLY PROCESSED FOR NEWLY ADDED PHASE IV MINERALS AND OTHER MINERALS NOT INCLUDED IN EARTH MRI, BUT POTENTIALLY SIGNIFICANT FOR THE MINING INDUSTRY AT LARGE. A DATA PRESERVATION PLAN WILL BE CREATED TO ENSURE PROPER DATA MANAGEMENT. WGS STAFF WILL ALSO PARTICIPATE IN THE EARTH MRI WORKSHOP ON EVALUATIONS OF MINE WASTE SURFACE DEPOSITS.

OUR MINES WEB APP WILL BE EXPANDED BY INCORPORATING ADDITIONAL MINERAL PROPERTY FILES AND ANNUAL IDAHO  MINING AND EXPLORATION REVIEWS. IN ADDITION, A PILOT DATABASE AND WORKFLOW FOR CATALOGING IMAGES CURATED  BY THE IDAHO GEOLOGICAL SURVEY WILL BE DEVELOPED. WE WILL ALSO DEVELOP A PILOT DATABASE, WORKFLOW, AND  WEB APP FOR DISSEMINATING LIDAR-DERIVED PRODUCTS, AND RE-BOX WELL CUTTINGS.IDAHO CONTAINS NUMEROUS MINES WITH PRODUCED OR REPORTED CRITICAL MINERALS. EXAMPLES INCLUDE CO, REE,  NB, V, F, SB, W, BI, AND ZN. PROJECT TITLE:DATA PRESERVATION AND CRITICAL MINERALS ACTIVITIES IN IOWA 2022-2023PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023THIS GRANT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE IOWA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (IGS) TO COMPLETE 3 PROJECTS FOR THE NATIONAL GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA PRESERVATION PROGRAM. THE PROJECTS ARE INCORPORATING A DATABASE OF SITES WITH ALLUVIAL STRATIGRAPHIC NOMENCLATURE INTO ITS DATABASES, CREATE NEW SHELVING FOR WELL CUTTING STORAGE, AND DEVELOP PROCEDURES AND WORKFLOWS TO CONVERT GEOPHYSICAL LOGS TO LAS FILE.A DATASET OF OVER 3,800 SITES CONTAINING DETAILED, REGIONAL ALLUVIAL STRATIGRAPHIC NOMENCLATURE WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO IGS DATABASES. COMPLETING THE PROJECT REQUIRES IGS STAFF TO RUN QUERIES AGAINST THE ORIGINAL DATA TO ELIMINATE DUPLICATE RECORDS, GENERATE SCRIPTS TO REFORMAT THE DATASET, REVIEW DATA FOR PROBLEMS OR INCONSISTENCIES, AND FINALLY UPLOAD THE DATA TO IGS DATABASES. THE IGS WILL THEN HIRE STUDENT TO UPLOAD HISTORIC PAPER RECORDS AND REPORTS ASSOCIATED THE DATASET INTO ITS DATABASES. FREE IGS WEB APPLICATIONS AND GIS COVERAGES WILL ALLOW THE PUBLIC TO ACCESS THE DATA. ADDITIONALLY, A COLLECTION IN THE NATIONAL DIGITAL CATALOG WILL BE UPDATE TO INCREASE DISCOVERABILITY OF THE DATA. THE DATASET WILL AID IGS GEOLOGIST IN THE CREATION OF SURFICIAL GEOLOGIC MAPS AND OTHER RESEARCHERS FOR A MYRIAD OF OTHER RESEARCH PROJECTS.THE IGS WILL EXPAND ITS CUTTING STORAGE REPOSITORY AREA. THE IGS' CURRENT CUTTING STORAGE AREA IN NEARLY FULL. THE IGS WILL CONSTRUCT NEW-WOODEN SHELVING ON AN EXISTING MEZZANINE. PRIOR TO SHELVING CONSTRUCTION, THE MEZZANINE THE WILL BE STRUCTURALLY REINFORCED TO HANDLE THE ADDITION WEIGHT LOAD. THE NEW WOODEN SHELVING WILL BE CONSTRUCTED IDENTICAL TO EXISTING SHELVES, MEET THE REQUIRED LOAD CAPACITY, AND FALL WITHIN SAFETY REQUIREMENTS. THE EXPANSION IS ANTICIPATED TO PROVIDE SUFFICIENT SHELVING SPACE FOR THE IGS TO INVENTORY AND STORE CUTTING SAMPLES FOR THE NEXT 10 YEARS.THE IGS DEVELOP PROCEDURES AND WORKFLOWS FOR CONVERTING GEOPHYSICAL LOGS TO LAS. THE IGS HAS SCANNED JPGS OF OVER 3,000 UNIQUE GEOPHYSICAL LOGS IN ITS ARCHIVE. THE PROCEDURES AND WORKFLOWS WILL BE ESTABLISHED BY CONVERTING A SUBSET OF THESE GEOPHYSICAL LOGS, THOSE RELATED TO CRITICAL MINERAL INVESTIGATION IN ORDOVICIAN SEDIMENTARY UNITS, TO LAS FORMAT. THE IGS WILL OBTAIN A SOFTWARE LICENSE FOR NEURALOG PRO, A COMMERCIAL PRODUCT USED BY OTHER STATE SURVEYS TO CONVERT IMAGES TO LAS FORMAT. IGS STAFF WILL TEST NEURALOG PRO'S CAPABILITIES TO ESTABLISH EFFICIENT PROCEDURES AND WORKFLOWS TO CONVERT FILES. AFTER ESTABLISHING THE PROCEDURES AND WORKFLOWS, THE IGS WILL HIRE STUDENT INTERNS TO CONVERT ADDITIONAL LOGS. A MINIMUM OF 75 LOGS WILL BE CONVERTED TO LAS FORMAT. THE FINALIZED LAS FORMAT FILES WILL BE UPLOADED TO AN IGS WEB APPLICATION TO ALLOW FOR FREE PUBLIC ACCESS. THE IGS WILL ALSO CREATE A COLLECTION IN THE NATIONAL DIGITAL CATALOG TO INCREASE THE DISCOVERABILITY OF THE LAS FORMAT FILES. THE CONVERSION OF SCANNED GEOPHYSICAL LOGS TO LAS FORMAT WILL ALLOW THE IGS STAFF, AND OTHERS, TO ACCESS GEOPHYSICAL DATA IN A FORMAT COMPATIBLE WITH A VARIETY OF GEOLOGIC SOFTWARE PLATFORMS FOR DATA MODELING. FURTHERMORE, THE CONVERSION OF THESE DATA PRESERVED IN THESE ARCHIVED GEOPHYSICAL LOGS INTO LAS FORMAT WILL BE A GREAT CONTRIBUTION TO THE SEARCH FOR CRITICAL MINERALS IN THE STATE.

PROJECT TITLE:KENTUCKY GEOLOGICAL SURVEY FY2022 GEOLOGIC DATA PRESERVATION PROJECTPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 6/1/2022 THROUGH 5/31/2023AWARDED FUNDS WILL BE USED TO IMPROVE ACCESSIBILITY AND PRESERVATION OF SEVERAL DATA COLLECTION  AT THE KENTUCKY GEOLOGICAL SURVEY. THE ACTIVITIES, OUTCOMES, AND BENEFICIARIES WILL VARY FOR EACH  COLLECTION.  FIRST, OVER 700 SOIL CORES AND ASSOCIATED PLUGS WILL BE IDENTIFIED AND ASSESSED FOR RESEARCH  VIABILITY, MADE AVAILABLE ONLINE, AND REFRIGERATION STORAGE WILL BE SET UP TO INCREASE THEIR  LONGEVITY OF USE. PROJECT STAFF WILL ALSO REHOUSE SALVAGED CORES INTO D TUBES AND REGISTER SALVAGED CORES WITH IGSNS. THE MAJOR DELIVERABLE IS A WELL-ORGANIZED AND PUBLICLY AVAILABLE  COLLECTION OF KENTUCKY SOIL CORES. THIS DELIVERABLE WILL BENEFIT KGS STAFF, UNDERGRADUATE AND  GRADUATE STUDENTS, AND SOIL SCIENTISTS IN KENTUCKY INTERESTED IN VARIOUS AREAS INCLUDING CLIMATE  CHANGE, GEOHEALTH, AND AGRICULTURE.SECOND, THE KGS DYE TRACE DATASET WILL BE MODERNIZED TO CONFORM TO FAIR DATA STANDARDS AND  IMPROVE ITS OVERALL USEABILITY. PROJECT STAFF WILL 1) DEVELOP CONSISTENT DATA DICTIONARIES, 2) UPDATE  DATA FIELDS AND ATTRIBUTES IN ALL GEOSPATIAL FEATURES TO MATCH THE DATA DICTIONARY, AND 3) UPDATE  METADATA TO INCLUDE MORE DETAILS ON THE DATA SOURCE, AND THE SCALE OF USEABILITY, AND THE DATA  LIMITATIONS. THE MAJOR DELIVERABLE IS A DATASET WITH THE NECESSARY INFORMATION TO ENSURE  APPROPRIATE USE BY THE PUBLIC IN A VARIETY OF PROJECTS. THESE DELIVERABLES WILL BENEFIT RESEARCHERS  INTERESTED IN THE KARST LANDSCAPE OF KENTUCKY.THIRD, PAPER DOCUMENTS REPRESENTING 2,888 ROCK CORES WILL BE CENTRALIZED, ORGANIZED, INVENTORIED,  AND SCANNED AT 300 DPI FOR ONLINE DISSEMINATION. THE MAJOR DELIVERABLE IS A DIGITAL COLLECTION OF  ROCK CORE DOCUMENTS AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC ONLINE PROVIDING WELL-DETAILED INFORMATION FOR EACH  CORE VIA SEVERAL OF THE KGS SEARCH AND MAP SERVICES. THIS DELIVERABLE WILL MAKE CORE SELECTION  AND USE MUCH EASIER FOR RESEARCHERS AND BENEFIT THE PATRONS OF THE KGS EARTH ANALYSIS RESEARCH  LIBRARY INTERESTED IN USING OUR ROCK CORE COLLECTION FOR THEIR RESEARCH. THE COLLECTION CAN BE USED  FOR A VARIETY OF STUDY AREAS INCLUDING HYDROCARBON DISCOVERY, PALEOCLIMATE, AND ENVIRONMENTAL  STUDIES.FOURTH, SIX HUNDRED AND FORTY-SIX DIGITAL FILES WILL BE ADDED TO THE KENTUCKY MINERAL RESOURCES  INFORMATION MAP SERVICE. PROJECT STAFF WILL THEN 1) REVIEW CA. 5,000 NON-SEARCHABLE FILES AND  ENTER KEY DATA INTO TABULATED DATASETS AND DATABASES, 2) DIGITIZE MAPS, AND 3) IDENTIFY CROSS-SECTIONS FOR INCORPORATION INTO THE ONGOING 3D MODELING OF THE ILLINOIS-KENTUCKY FLUORSPAR  DISTRICT. MAJOR DELIVERABLES OF THE PROJECT ARE DIGITAL DATABASES THAT WILL CONTAIN ASSAY RESULTS AND  MINERALOGICAL INFORMATION, AND AN IMPROVED VERSION OF THE MAP SERVICE THAT WILL INCLUDE ALL FILES  AND UPDATES. THESE DELIVERABLES WILL BENEFIT ONGOING AND FUTURE KGS RESEARCH AND PROVIDE KEY  INSIGHTS FOR THE NATIONAL CONVERSATION ABOUT CRITICAL MINERAL EXPLORATION.

PROJECT TITLE:ALASKA GMC DATABASE UPGRADE, HYPERSPECTRAL SCANNER, AND CORE RESCUEPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023THE PURPOSE OF THE GRANT AWARDED TO THE WYOMING STATE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY IS TO PAY TRAVEL EXPENSES FOR TWO STAFF MEMBERS TO PARTICIPATE IN THE 2022 NATIONAL GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA PRESERVATION PROGRAM PRESERVATION WORKSHOP IN BUTTE, MONTANA.THE 2022 NATIONAL GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA PRESERVATION PROGRAM PRESERVATION WORKSHOP WILL BE HOSTED BY THE MONTANA BUREAU OF MINING AND GEOLOGY IN EARLY FALL 2022. THE WORKSHOP IS COSPONSORED BY THE NATIONAL GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA PRESERVATION PROGRAM AND THE ASSOCIATION OF AMERICAN STATE GEOLOGISTS. WYOMING STATE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY WORKSHOP PARTICIPATION WILL PROVIDE OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN ABOUT BEST PRACTICES IN GEOLOGIC DATA PRESERVATION. WHILE ATTENDING THE WORKSHOP, WYOMING STATE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY STAFF WILL USE THEIR KNOWLEDGE OF WYOMING STATE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY COLLECTIONS, METADATA, GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS, DATABASE DESIGN, AND GEOLOGY TO HELP DEVELOP FUTURE PROJECTS FOR DATA PRESERVATION AND DISTRIBUTION. THE PRIMARY GOAL FOR ATTENDING THIS WORKSHOP IS FOR THE WYOMING STATE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY STAFF TO IMPROVE THEIR OWN PROGRAMS BY LEARNING DATA PRESERVATION TECHNIQUES, WORKFLOWS, AND PROJECTS PERFORMED IN OTHER STATES.

PROJECT TITLE:PRIORITY 1: DIGITAL PRESERVATION AND WEB-BASED DELIVERYOF BOREHOLE LITHOLOGY LOG DATAPERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/2022 THROUGH 6/30/2023A REFRACTION/WIDE-ANGLE REFLECTION EXPERIMENT IS PROPOSED TO DETERMINE P- AND S-WAVE VELOCITY  AND ANELASTIC ATTENUATION OF A DEEP SECTION OF MISSISSIPPI EMBAYMENT SEDIMENTS IN THE  MISSISSIPPI RIVER PLAIN NEAR MEMPHIS, TN. THE EXPERIMENT WILL CONSIST OF DETONATING TWO 200LB  BURIED EXPLOSIVE SOURCES AT THE ENDS OF A 3KM LINEAR ARRAY OF 60 THREE-COMPONENT, 5 HZ  AUTONOMOUS NODAL SEISMOMETERS. THE IRIS SEISMIC SOURCE FACILITY AT THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS,  EL PASO, WILL BE PROVIDING THE EXPLOSIVE SOURCES AND OVERSEEING ALL EMPLACEMENT AND CLEANUP  ACTIVITIES AT THE SITE. AN ADDITIONAL STRONG MOTION GRADIOMETER CONSISTING OF 16 MEMS THREECOMPONENT ACCELEROMETERS WILL BE DEPLOYED 50M FROM EACH EXPLOSION TO RECORD STRONG GROUND  MOTIONS AND ANALYZE THE SOURCE FUNCTIONS OF EACH EXPLOSION. SMALL SCALE REFRACTION AND  REFLECTION PROFILES WILL ALSO BE COLLECTED AT EACH SOURCE POINT TO CHARACTERIZE THE SHALLOW SOURCE  MEDIUM. WE WILL COLLECT A CANONICAL, HIGH SIGNAL-TO-NOISE, DENSELY SAMPLED DATASET OF BODY AND  SURFACE WAVES THAT WILL BE MODELED TO DETERMINE BOTH VELOCITY AND ATTENUATION STRUCTURE OF THE  SEDIMENTARY COLUMN. THIS RESEARCH DIRECTLY ADDRESSES THREE PRIORITY TOPICS FOR THE CEUS  INCLUDING "IMPROVING AND REDUCING UNCERTAINTIES IN ESTIMATES OF STRONG GROUND MOTION FOR THE  NATIONAL SEISMIC HAZARD MODEL, AND IN PARTICULAR FOR AREAS WITH EXTENSIVE SEDIMENT LAYERS SUCH  AS THE ATLANTIC COASTAL PLAIN AND MISSISSIPPI EMBAYMENT REGIONS", "CHARACTERIZE WAVE  PROPAGATION AND ATTENUATION IN THE CEUS INCLUDING BASIN EFFECTS", AND "IMPROVE ESTIMATES OF SITE  RESPONSE AND LIQUEFACTION POTENTIAL USING FIELD EXPERIMENTS OR INSTRUMENTAL RECORDINGS, WITH AN  EMPHASIS ON GEOLOGIC UNITS THAT UNDERLIE LARGE AREAS OF THE CEUS." ALTHOUGH IT HAS BEEN LONG  RECOGNIZED THAT THE VELOCITY AND ATTENUATION STRUCTURE OF EMBAYMENT SEDIMENTS ARE ESSENTIAL PARTS  OF ESTIMATING THE SHAKING HAZARDS OF EARTHQUAKES FROM THE NEW MADRID SEISMIC ZONE, IT IS  SURPRISING THAT THERE ARE NO CONTROLLED SOURCE SEISMIC DATASETS THAT HAVE BEEN COLLECTED TO  EXAMINE THE ENTIRE VELOCITY PROFILE OF THE SEDIMENTS AND HOW ACTUAL P AND S WAVES PROPAGATE  THROUGH THEM. IN THE PROPOSED ESEE 2022 RESEARCH, ANALYSIS METHODS FOR CONSTRUCTING INITIAL  VELOCITY MODELS INCLUDE SEISMIC RAY THEORY FOR OBSERVED P- AND S-WAVE BODY WAVE ARRIVALS AND  USE OF DISPERSION MEASUREMENTS FROM OBSERVED SURFACE WAVES. FINAL ATTENUATION AND VELOCITY  STRUCTURE WILL BE INFERRED FROM WAVEFORM AMPLITUDES AND PHASES USING FULL WAVEFORM INVERSION  OF THE ENTIRE DATASET. THE DATA COLLECTED IN ESEE 2022 WILL ENABLE A DETERMINATION OF THE IN-SITU  VELOCITY AND ATTENUATION STRUCTURE FOR BOTH P- AND S-WAVES AS GROUND TRUTH FOR MODELS OF  SEDIMENT AMPLIFICATION USED IN HAZARD STUDIES AND TO SERVE AS A PROTOTYPE EXPERIMENT FOR FURTHER  EXPLORATION OF STRUCTURE OF EMBAYMENT SEDIMENT.

PRIORITY 1 HAS THREE COMPONENTS. THE FIRST COMPONENT (PRIORITY 1A) SEEKS FUNDING TO: 1) PROVIDE A DETAILED  INVENTORY OF HISTORIC GEOLOGIC AND EXPLORATION PAPER REPORTS OF ORE DEPOSITS MAINTAINED BY THE COLORADO  GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (CGS) TO SUPPORT FUTURE DIGITIZATION EFFORTS, 2) CONVERT GOLD-DEPOSIT MAPS FROM PAPER  PUBLICATIONS INTO DIGITAL FORMAT USING ARCGIS WITH ATTRIBUTES AND NATIONAL DIGITAL CATALOG (NDC)  STANDARDIZED METADATA AND, 3) CONVERT COUNTY-WIDE GEOLOGIC MAPS TO GEMS LEVEL 2 FORMAT. FOR ITEMS 1  AND 2, THIS WILL MAKE THE DATA READILY ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC AND BENEFIT RESEARCHERS AND INVESTIGATORS  ESPECIALLY WITH REGARDS TO GOLD AND OTHER ORE DEPOSITS WITHIN THE STATE. THE DATA SETS CONSIST OF GEOLOGICAL  AND EXPLORATION DATA (CA.1960S-1990S), INCLUDING GEOLOGICAL DRILLING INFORMATION AND MAPS ASSOCIATED  WITH PRECIOUS METALS, BASE METAL, AND OTHER MINERAL DEPOSITS THAT WERE DONATED TO THE CGS OVER THE LAST  SEVERAL DECADES, AND STATEWIDE GOLD-DEPOSIT MAPS ORIGINALLY PUBLISHED IN 1990 BY THE CGS (DAVIS AND  STREUFERT, 1990). THESE MATERIALS ARE IN THE PUBLIC DOMAIN. FOR ITEM 3, THE CONVERSION OF THE MAPS TO  GEMS LEVEL 2 WILL ALLOW THESE DATA TO BE EASILY INCORPORATED INTO OTHER CGS MAPPING PROJECTS SUCH AS  STATEMAP AND MINERAL/AGGREGATE RESOURCE MAPPING, AND USGS-SPONSORED PROJECTS SUCH AS THE  GEOFRAMEWORK INITIATIVE.  THE SECOND COMPONENT (PRIORITY 1B) SEEKS FUNDING TO CONVERT GEOLOGIC MATERIALS FROM PAPER INTO DIGITAL  FORMAT WITH NDC METADATA. CGS WILL MAKE THE DATA READILY ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC AND BENEFIT  RESEARCHERS AND INVESTIGATORS. THE DATASET CONSISTS OF GEOLOGIC, GEOLOGIC HAZARD, AND GEOTECHNICAL REPORTS  AND MAPS DATING FROM 1972 TO THE PRESENT COLLECTED BY THE CGS FROM SUBMITTALS OF LAND-USE EVALUATION  STUDIES. THESE MATERIALS ARE IN THE PUBLIC DOMAIN.  THE THIRD COMPONENT (PRIORITY 1C) IS TO PRESERVE, INVENTORY, STORE, SCAN AND CREATE DIGITAL IMAGES OF  10,000 FEET OF CORE AND ASSOCIATED WELL DATA. THE CORE WAS DONATED BY WHITING OIL AND GAS CORPORATION  AND INCLUDES THE DENVER BASIN. THE PROJECT INCLUDES PRESERVING THE CORE BY SLABBING AND BOXING; CREATING  STORAGE SPACE BY INSTALLING NEW CORE RACKS; AND INVENTORYING AND ORGANIZING THE CORE. ASSOCIATED WELL  DATA WILL BE INVENTORIED, SCANNED, AND DIGITIZED. CGS WILL STORE DIGITAL IMAGES OF ALL CORES ON A WEB-BASED SYSTEM WHICH WILL MAKE DATA AND METADATA RETRIEVAL POSSIBLE. THE PROJECT WILL PRESERVE A MUCH NEEDED CORE DATA SET AND MAKE IT AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC, STUDENTS, AND RESEARCHERS.  UNDER PRIORITY 2, THE CGS WILL ASSIST WITH THE DELINEATION AND REVIEW OF CRITICAL MINERAL FOCUS AREAS AND  ATTEND THE CRITICAL MINERALS WORKSHOP.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION: THE MICHIGAN GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (MGS), TOGETHER WITH ITS REPOSITORY, THE MICHIGAN GEOLOGICAL REPOSITORY FOR RESEARCH AND EDUCATION (MGRRE), BOTH PART OF THE DEPARTMENT OF GEOLOGICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES AT WESTERN MICHIGAN UNIVERSITY (WMU), WILL PRESERVE AND CREATE DIGITAL ACCESS TO THREE SETS OF CORE SAMPLES AND DATA. WE WILL (1) SCAN ALL ON-SITE CORE ANALYSES FROM 2407 WELLS, PROVIDING COMPREHENSIVE CORE PROPERTIES DATA ESSENTIAL TO RESERVOIR CHARACTERIZATION AND AGGREGATE RESOURCE DISCOVERY. OF THOSE 2407 WELLS, WE ARCHIVE THIN SECTIONS AND CORES FOR 191 WELLS, FOR WHICH WE WILL (2) CREATE HIGH RESOLUTION DIGITAL SCANS OF 3006 THIN SECTIONS AND (3) PRODUCE HIGH-RESOLUTION DIGITAL CORE PHOTOGRAPHS OF 3550 CORE BOXES. WE WILL MAKE ALL THESE DIGITAL PRODUCTS FREELY AVAILABLE ON-LINE THROUGH SCHOLARWORKS, A WORLD WIDE WEB ARCHIVE SITE USED BY WESTERN MICHIGAN UNIVERSITY. WE WILL ALSO CREATE ADDITIONAL PHYSICAL INFRASTRUCTURE TO SUPPORT PRESERVING PHYSICAL SAMPLES AND DATA. ALL THESE RESOURCES ARE NOW AVAILABLE ON-SITE ONLY. THROUGH THIS WORK, USERS WILL BE ABLE TO ACCESS COMPREHENSIVE DATA FROM CORE ANALYSES AND VISUALLY/VIRTUALLY EXAMINE IMAGES OF RELATED CORES AND THIN SECTIONS. THIS INFORMATION IS ESSENTIAL TO SUPPORT CLIMATE STUDIES, SUBSURFACE RESOURCE ASSESSMENTS, AND ASSOCIATED PHYSICAL INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT. OUR GOAL IS TO INCREASE RESOURCE DISCOVERY BY RESEARCHERS, RESOURCE MANAGERS, DECISION-MAKERS, AND THE PUBLIC, TO PROVIDE SOCIETAL AND SCIENTIFIC BENEFITS.PRIMARY USERS AND FREQUENCY OF USE: MGS' PRIMARY USERS ARE MEMBERS OF ACADEMIA, INDUSTRY, PLANNERS, AND GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES. FACULTY AND STUDENTS USE THIS FACILITY DAILY. PRIOR TO COVID, OTHER STAKEHOLDERS VISITED THE FACILITY 1-3 TIMES/MONTH AND ABOUT 150 PEOPLE ATTENDED OUR ANNUAL WORKSHOPS. THOSE NUMBERS ARE NOW REDUCED BY ABOUT HALF. WEB PAGES RECEIVE ABOUT 7,000 VISITORS/MONTH.SOCIETAL AND SCIENTIFIC BENEFITS PROVIDED THROUGH THIS PRESERVATION WORK: CORES ARE UNIQUE SOURCES OF CONTINUOUS VERTICAL SAMPLES OF SUBSURFACE GEOLOGICAL FORMATIONS THAT CAN BE VISUALLY EXAMINED AND SAMPLED TO DETERMINE ROCK TYPE, SEDIMENTARY STRUCTURES, RESERVOIR CHARACTER, AND DEPOSITIONAL HISTORY. CORE DATA IS CRITICAL TO ASSESSING SUBSURFACE RESOURCES SUCH AS MINERAL DEPOSITS, HYDROTHERMAL ENERGY RESOURCES, AND CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS INCLUDING SAND, GRAVEL AND CRUSHED STONE. ASSESSING THE QUALITY AND QUANTITY OF THOSE MATERIALS DIRECTLY SUPPORTS ECONOMIC EXPANSION AND ASSOCIATED INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT. IN MICHIGAN, CORE DATA IS ESSENTIAL TO CLIMATE STUDIES, E.G., CARBON CAPTURE, UTILIZATION AND STORAGE (CCUS), WHICH MGS HAS BEEN CARRYING OUT FOR SEVERAL YEARS. CCUS PROVIDES A CRITICAL PATH TO MEET NET-ZERO GOALS IN MICHIGAN AND GLOBALLY. CORE DATA PROVIDED THROUGH THIS PROJECT WILL SHED LIGHT ON SEVERAL FORMATIONS THAT MAY PROVIDE THE BEST OPPORTUNITIES FOR LARGE-SCALE CCUS. AND, BECAUSE CORE DATA IDENTIFIES DEPTHS TO AND QUALITIES OF BUILDING MATERIALS, PLANNERS CAN USE THIS DATA TO MORE RELIABLY AND ECONOMICALLY SOURCE THESE MATERIALS WHERE THEY ARE NEEDED FOR ROADS, BRIDGES, AND OTHER CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS.

THE ARIZONA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY HAS BEEN MAKING GEOLOGIC MAPS OF THE SOUTHWESTERN UNITED STATES FOR OVER ONE HUNDRED YEARS. MANY OF ITS MAPS PRE-DATE THE ADOPTION OF PERSONAL COMPUTERS AND WERE HAND-DRAFTED ON PAPER. ALTHOUGH THESE OLDER MAPS HAVE SINCE BEEN CONVERTED INTO COMPUTER IMAGES, THEY LACK SUFFICIENT DETAIL FOR USE IN MODERN GEOLOGICAL ANALYSIS. THE ARIZONA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY IS THEREFORE WORKING WITH THE NATIONAL GEOPHYSICAL AND GEOLOGICAL DATA PRESERVATION PROGRAM TO RETRACE 30 OF ITS OLDER MAPS INTO MODERN COMPUTER FORMATS TO BETTER SERVE THE RESEARCH COMMUNITY. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED AS PART OF THIS WORK ARE THE UPLOAD OF SCANNED IMAGES INTO MAPMAKING SOFTWARE, RETRACING THEM AS DIGITAL IMAGES, AND THEN PROOFREADING OR EDITING THEM TO CONFORM TO MODERN DATA STANDARDS. A DIGITAL PACKET OF THE NEWLY PRESERVED IMAGES WILL THEN BE REPUBLISHED AND DELIVERED TO VARIOUS ONLINE REPOSITORIES SUCH AS THE NATIONAL GEOLOGIC MAP DATABASE. THESE MAPS WILL BENEFIT GEOLOGIC RESEARCHERS IN PRIVATE INDUSTRY, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, AND ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS.MINING, IN ONE SHAPE OR ANOTHER, HAS OCCURRED IN ARIZONA FOR AS LONG AS PEOPLE HAVE LIVED IN THESE LANDS. A TREMENDOUS AMOUNT OF GEOLOGIC INFORMATION DURING MINERAL EXPLORATION AND MINING HAS BEEN CREATED OVER THE YEARS, INCLUDING DETAILS ON PROSPECT/MINE LOCATIONS, WHAT MINERALS WERE MINED, AND THE QUANTITIES OF ROCK MINED. THIS INFORMATION HAS, HOWEVER, NEVER BEEN PULLED TOGETHER INTO A SINGLE LOCATION. THE ARIZONA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY IS COLLECTING THIS INFORMATION INTO A SINGLE PUBLICATION TO PROVIDE BASIC GEOLOGIC DATA TO THE PUBLIC, POLICYMAKERS, AND EXPLORERS TO MAKE MORE INFORMED DECISIONS REGARDING NATURAL RESOURCE USE. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED AS PART OF THIS WORK INCLUDE: 1) PARTICIPATION WITH THE 2022 USGS CRITICAL MINERALS WORKSHOP; 2) COMPILATION OF MINERAL DEPOSIT/DISTRICT DATA THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE USGS MAP COMPILATION OF FOCUS AREAS, AND 3) COMPILE MINERAL DEPOSIT DATA FOR ALL KNOWN DEPOSITS AND PROSPECTS FOR GREENLEE COUNTY, ARIZONA INTO A REVIEW PUBLICATION ON THE MINERAL RESOURCE POTENTIAL OF GREENLEE COUNTY, ARIZONA.

IN PAST YEARS THIS GRANT HAS FUNDED MANY PROJECTS AT THE NEW MEXICO BUREAU OF GEOLOGY AND MINERAL  RESOURCES (NMBGMR) IN SCANNING AND CATALOGING OUR COLLECTIONS. THIS INFORMATION HAS BEEN USED IN  RESEARCH AND EDUCATION BY STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, INDUSTRY, AND THE PUBLIC. TO HELP OUR SHAREHOLDERS  GAIN ACCESS QUICKLY TO OUR ARCHIVES WE HAVE BEEN PUTTING OUR DATA ONLINE AS IT BECOMES AVAILABLE DIGITALLY.  FUNDING RECEIVED FROM THIS GRANT WILL AID NMBGMR IN DEVELOPING INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS AND MAKING  MORE DATA AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC. IN PRIORITY 1 DATA PRESERVATION PROJECTS, CRITICAL MINERAL DATA WILL BE  SCANNED AND UPLOADED TO NMBGMR'S ONLINE ARCHIVE ALONG WITH SCANS DONE PREVIOUSLY UNDER THIS GRANT TO  MAKE THEM AVAILABLE ONLINE. ALSO, PRIORITY 1 WILL FOCUS ON CREATING A CORE PHOTO CENTER, PHOTOGRAPHING 10  WELL CORES WITH POTENTIAL CRITICAL MINERALS, AND DEVELOPING A SUBSURFACE DATABASE FOLLOWING NATIONAL INDEX OF BOREHOLE INFORMATION (NIBI) STANDARDS. INFRASTRUCTURE WILL BE ADDED IN THE FORM OF A FORKLIFT TO  TRANSPORT CORE AND ADDED STORAGE FOR ONLINE OR BACKUP DATA STORAGE NEEDS. PRIORITY 2 CRITICAL MINERALS IN YEAR 4, WILL REVISE SOME OF THE DELIVERABLES IN 2019-2021 BY UTILIZING THE  NEWLY DEVELOPED USGS STANDARD TEMPLATE AND MINERALS SYSTEMS APPROACH TO DEFINING MINERAL DEPOSITS  WITH CRITICAL MINERALS IN NM. WE WILL ALSO FOCUS ON ZINC AND NICKEL AS WELL AS MINE WASTES. THE  NMBGMR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE CONTINUED REVISION AND DEVELOPMENT OF NM'S LONG-RANGE  PLAN ON COMPILING INFORMATION ON CRITICAL MINERALS IN NM, CONTINUED COMPILATION OF GIS SHAPEFILES OF  CRITICAL MINERALS IN MINING DISTRICTS USING THE USGS DISTRICTS_EARTHMRI TEMPLATE, A COMPILATION OF  CRITICAL MINERAL POTENTIAL IN MINE WASTES (MINE DUMPS, TAILINGS), CONTINUED COMPILATION OF A DATABASE OF  CHEMICAL ANALYSES OF ROCKS AND MINERAL, DEVELOPMENT OF A DATABASE AND ARCHIVE OF ORE, MINERALIZED  SAMPLES, AND OTHER SAMPLES WITH CRITICAL MINERAL POTENTIAL, AND UTILIZING PRIORITY 1 PHOTO CENTER TO  PHOTOGRAPH AND DESCRIBE CORE WITH CRITICAL MINERALS POTENTIAL. DELIVERABLES FOR PRIORITY 2 WILL BE A REVISED  LONG-RANGE PLAN AND DATABASES, PHOTOGRAPHS AND DESCRIPTIONS OF CORES FROM AREAS WITH POTENTIAL CRITICAL  MINERALS, AND SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS AND FILES FOR THE USGS CRITICAL MINERAL RESOURCES WORKSHOP. DELIVERABLES OF PRIORITY 1 AND 2 WILL BE AVAILABLE ONLINE THROUGH THE NMBGMR WEB PAGES, OPEN FILE  REPORTS, PUBLISHED REPORTS, USGS WEBSITES, OR BY REQUEST. WORKSHOPS WILL BE ATTENDED FOR BOTH PRIORITY 1  AND 2.

THE CALIFORNIA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (CGS) MINERAL RESOURCES PROGRAM IS REQUESTING MATCHING FUNDS TO SEND FOUR STAFF TO TWO WORKSHOPS IN 2022. THE FIRST WORKSHOP IS HOSTED BY THE USGS NATIONAL GEOLOGICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL DATA PRESERVATION PROGRAM (NGGDPP) IN BUTTE, MT FROM AUGUST 29TH - SEPTEMBER 1ST, 2022. THIS WORKSHOP WILL FOCUS ON HOW STATE GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS ARE WORKING TOWARD GEOSCIENCE DATA PRESERVATION IN SUPPORT OF THE NGGDPP'S GOAL TO PROMOTE THE AVAILABILITY OF GEOLOGICAL DATA FOR THE PUBLIC.THE SECOND WORKSHOP IS HOSTED BY THE USGS EARTH MAPPING RESOURCES INITIATIVE (EARTH MRI) IN FORT COLLINS, CO IN FALL 2022. THIS WORKSHOP WILL BRING TOGETHER STATE GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS TO AID IN DEVELOPMENT OF GEOSPATIAL DATA SETS TO BE USED IN IDENTIFYING AND PRIORITIZING FOCUS AREAS THAT ARE KNOWN OR HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO HOST CRITICAL MINERALS IN THE US.THE CGS MINERAL RESOURCES PROGRAM HAS THREE ACTIVE GRANTS WITH THE USGS THAT FALL UNDER GEOLOGICAL DATA PRESERVATION AND CRITICAL MINERAL RESOURCE IDENTIFICATION ACTIVITIES. THE ATTENDEES SELECTED FOR THESE WORKSHOPS EACH HAVE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR AND/OR INVESTIGATOR ROLES ON SEVERAL CURRENT AND PAST USGS GRANTS. THESE WORKSHOPS WILL PROVIDE IMPORTANT INFORMATION TO SUPPORT THE COMPLETION OF OUR UPCOMING GRANT DELIVERABLES AND FOR FUTURE PROJECT PLANNING.

THE FLORIDA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY'S GEOLOGIC SAMPLE COLLECTION FACILITY CONTAINS OVER 75,000 BOXES  OF CORE AND CUTTINGS SAMPLES FOR ALMOST 20,000 BOREHOLES FROM FLORIDA. AFTER INVENTORYING  UNPROCESSED SAMPLES, THE FLORIDA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY HAS IDENTIFIED 7,500 CUTTINGS SAMPLES FROM  31 UNDERGROUND INJECTION CONTROL WELLS THAT NEED TO BE PROCESSED AND CURATED. THESE WELLS VARY IN DEPTH FROM 500 TO OVER 10,000 FEET AND COVER A TOTAL FOOTAGE OF 75,000 FEET. THE SAMPLES HAVE  AN ESTIMATED REPLACEMENT COST OF $8.5 MILLION. IT IS THE INTENT OF THE FLORIDA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY TO  PRESERVE THESE SAMPLES AND MAKE THE ASSOCIATED GEOLOGIC INFORMATION PUBLICLY AVAILABLE.OUR CUSTOMERS INCLUDE MUNICIPALITIES, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, WATER RESOURCE, MINERAL, AND  ENERGY COMPANIES AS WELL AS UNIVERSITY STUDENTS AND RESEARCH SCIENTISTS THROUGHOUT THE WORLD.  THERE ARE NUMEROUS SOCIETAL BENEFITS IN PRESERVING THIS INFORMATION AND MAKING THE ASSOCIATED GEOLOGIC DATA MORE ACCESSIBLE TO LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL AGENCIES. ON THE LOCAL AND STATE LEVEL,  THIS ACCESSIBILITY IMPROVES SITE-EVALUATION DECISIONS FOR WATER RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. INCREASED  PUBLICLY AVAILABLE GEOLOGIC DATA ASSISTS THE ONGOING MAPPING EFFORTS OF THE USGS FUNDED  STATEMAP AND EARTH MAPPING RESOURCES INITIATIVE PROJECTS.DURING THE PROJECT, EMPLOYEES WILL SORT CUTTINGS BY BOREHOLE AND DEPTH PRIOR TO PROCESSING. EACH  OF THE 7,500 CUTTINGS SAMPLES THAT ARE RECOVERABLE WILL BE SPLIT INTO TWO SAMPLE ENVELOPES. ONE  ENVELOPE WILL BE EARMARKED FOR FUTURE WASHING. ALL CUTTINGS SAMPLES WILL BE LABELLED AND STORED IN  CUTTINGS STORAGE BOXES. THESE PROCESSING ACTIVITIES WILL ADD APPROXIMATELY 600 NEW CUTTINGS BOXES  TO THE COLLECTION FACILITY.THERE ARE 21 BOREHOLES, WHICH REPRESENT 5,900 INTERVALS, THAT HAVE ASSOCIATED LITHOLOGIC  DESCRIPTIONS FOUND WITHIN THE WELL COMPLETION REPORTS. THESE DESCRIPTIONS WILL BE ENTERED INTO THE  FGS DATABASE BY STAFF MEMBERS USING CONTROLLED VOCABULARIES. ROCK TYPE IS REQUIRED FOR ALL  DESCRIPTION ENTRY. INDIVIDUAL INTERVAL DESCRIPTIONS ALSO MAY INCLUDE COLOR, GRAIN SIZE, INDURATION,  ACCESSORY MINERALS, AND GENERAL FOSSILS. LITHOLOGIC RECORDS WILL ALSO INCLUDE ENTRY OF FORMATION  PICKS, WHEN INDICATED.BOREHOLE LOCATIONS WILL BE VERIFIED BASED ON STATE-WIDE RECORDS BY EXPERIENCED STAFF. ANY  CORRESPONDING LITHOLOGIC DESCRIPTIONS ADDED TO THE DATABASE WILL BE VERIFIED BY A FLORIDA LICENSED PROFESSIONAL GEOLOGIST BEFORE BEING FULLY AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC. FINAL DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE  BOREHOLE DATA AND LITHOLOGIC INFORMATION MADE DIGITALLY AVAILABLE THROUGH THE FLORIDA GEOLOGICAL  SURVEY WEBSITE AND THE NATIONAL DIGITAL CATALOG.

THE MAINE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (MGS) RECENTLY RECEIVED A COLLECTION OF ROUGHLY 30,000 HISTORICAL  AERIAL PHOTOGRAPH PRINTS FROM THE MAINE DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION (MDOT). THESE PRINTS  WERE AT RISK OF BEING LOST IN A BUILDING RENOVATION. THEY ARE FOCUSED ON TRANSPORTATION PROJECTS  ACROSS THE STATE GOING BACK TO THE 1930S. MGS WILL FILE, INDEX, AND DIGITIZE THE FOOTPRINTS OF EACH  AIR PHOTO INTO OUR ENTERPRISE SPATIAL DATABASE AND ADD THIS COLLECTION TO OUR EXISTING, SCAN-ON-DEMAND AIR PHOTO WEB APPLICATION (HTTPS://WWW.MAINE.GOV/DACF/MGS/EXPLORE/MAPS/AIRPHOTOS/). MGS WILL ALSO UNDERTAKE A PLANNING PROJECT TO IDENTIFY A NEW LOCATION FOR CORE STORAGE IN AUGUSTA.  STAFF WILL ASSESS THE SPACE NEEDED FOR THE CURRENT COLLECTION AND DEVELOP AN ESTIMATE OF SPACE  NEEDED FOR FUTURE COLLECTION GROWTH AND BETTER WORKING CONDITIONS. RELIABLE ACCESS TO ROCK CORE  BENEFITS THE PRIVATE MINING COMPANIES LOOKING TO INVEST IN MAINE AND RESEARCH ORGANIZATIONS  LOOKING FOR BASIC DATA. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE MGS WITH THE DATA AND INTERNAL STATE  GOVERNMENT CONTACTS NEEDED TO APPLY FOR A NGGDPP GRANT IN 2023. A SUMMARY REPORT OF  BUILDING REQUIREMENTS, FACILITY OPTIONS, MOVING COSTS, AND SOFTWARE REQUIREMENTS WILL BE  SUBMITTED

ABSTRACT SUMMARY WITH HELP FROM THIS GRANT, WE WILL REACH TWO GOALS: TRANSFORM OUR CURRENT CRAMPED STORAGE SPACE  INTO A USER-FRIENDLY RECORD CENTER AND ADD ABOUT 26,000 DIGITAL FILES TO OUR ONLINE RESOURCE SYSTEM.ACTIVITIES ARCHIVES AND COLLECTIONS STAFF WILL CROSS-CHECK MINERAL AND ENERGY RECORDS AND ORGANIZE THEM BY  GEOGRAPHIC LOCATION. THEY WILL MOVE PAPER RECORDS INTO NEW BUFFERED, ACID-FREE ARCHIVAL BOXES AND CREATE BOX AND SHELF LABELS. THEY WILL HOUSE THE BOXES ON NEW MOBILE SHELVING, AND THEY WILL  SET UP AN ACCESS AREA FOR VISITORS IN THE RECORD CENTER. DIGITAL COLLECTIONS STAFF WILL SORT AND ORGANIZE PHOTOS OF ROCK CORES AND PDF FILES OF ROCK CORE CHEMISTRY. THEY WILL MOVE THE DIGITAL FILES INTO AN ONLINE RESOURCE SYSTEM CALLED CARST  (COLLECTIVEACCESS-RESOURCESPACE TANDEM) AND CREATE SEARCHABLE RECORDS IN THE SYSTEM. THEY  WILL THEN MAKE THE RECORDS VISIBLE TO THE PUBLIC.DELIVERABLES AND IMPACT THE ON-SITE RECORDS CENTER CREATES A SPACE THAT IS SAFE FOR VALUABLE GEOLOGICAL RECORDS AND  COMFORTABLE FOR ANYONE WHO WANTS TO UTILIZE THEM. THE NEW BOXES AND SHELVING WILL BETTER  PRESERVE, ORGANIZE, AND EXTEND THE LIFE OF THE RECORDS BY PROTECTING THEM FROM LIGHT, DUST, AND WEAR AND TEAR, WHILE SLOWING THE NATURAL AGING OF THE PAPER. ADDING RECORDS TO CARST WILL GIVE SCIENTISTS AND THE PUBLIC ACCESS TO RESOURCES THAT WERE HARD TO FIND OR NOT AVAILABLE BEFORE. ONCE IN THE SYSTEM, THE FILES CAN BE EASILY SEARCHED FOR, MANAGED,  AND PROTECTED FROM LOSS. BOTH ACCESS LOCATIONS PROVIDE USERS WITH A GATEWAY TO FINDING NON-BIASED GEOLOGICAL DATA. THESE  DATA CAN HELP GUIDE THE LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND GLOBAL USE OF INDIANA'S MINERAL AND ENERGY WEALTH AND  ADDRESS ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION CHALLENGES.
